tags: Am I still angry about Run/r?
And Infinity was killed because Disney got scared about toy-games
Disney look at Nintendo. All you have to do is make them a wee bit cheaper
Anyway I’m not surprised or upset by these news. It makes perfect sense tbh
summary:
After the news of Disney saying they’re pleased with EA and their Star Wars games:
Are you fucking surprised? This is the...
body:
After the news of Disney saying they’re pleased with EA and their Star Wars games:

Are you fucking surprised? This is the company that keeps killing their game-divisions. They murdered Disney Infinity, they slaughtered Tron Run/r, and that’s only a few of the game they’ve killed. Disney cannot, at all, make games. They would’ve killed off Battlefront the moment it didn’t recieve as much attention as Disney’s high expectations desires it to be. If it’s no success, they want to forget about it.

Of fucking course they’re happy with EA and their greed. It’s Disney. It doesn’t surprise me.

blog.name: douxreviews
blog.title: Doux Reviews
blog.description: Doux Reviews has been on the web since 2004 and features thousands of episode reviews of the best classic and current television shows, as well as many book and movie reviews. Please visit us!

summary: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005) Review
title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005) Review
body:
[This review includes spoilers. It was written right after I saw it in the theater.]

Padme: “So this is how liberty dies. With thunderous applause.”

I just saw Revenge of the Sith, and I can’t get it out of my head. For me, it’s up there with Empire, which has always been my favorite. This one is darker than Empire. It had to be. George Lucas deserves some heavy-duty praise after all the well-deserved criticism he took for Episodes One and Two.

During Episodes One and Two, I had some distance; I enjoyed them, but I couldn’t stop obsessing about what was wrong with them and they didn’t stay with me. They never felt like real Star Wars to me. But not this time. I was hooked from the first moment, and stayed completely absorbed until the final credits. Lucas gave us every single moment that we needed to see, tied up every loose end, and made it riveting at the same time. No stupid pod races, no Jar Jar (well, one second of Jar Jar, which was about right). The effects were out of this world, but they were there to support the story, which was what they were supposed to do.

It wasn’t a fun ride. I felt dread almost immediately, and just kept feeling it. It grew throughout, as we watched that beautiful young man lose his soul out of fear of losing his love. I was surprised that I desperately didn’t want Anakin to turn into Darth Vader, all the while knowing that it was inevitable. And I cried, twice. So did Dan, which almost never happens.

Ewan McGregor and Natalie Portman are big talents that were pretty much wasted in Episodes One and Two, but their talent certainly wasn’t wasted here. McGregor was terrific, clearly channeling Alec Guinness, and carrying so much of the drama. And Hayden Christensen – it’s really his movie more than anyone else’s, and frankly, I thought he was awesome. My heart just bled for him. Ian McDarmid, as the Emperor, was also very good, as was pretty much everyone else. There were no bad performances, or at least I didn’t notice any. The stilted Lucas dialogue was present, but it didn’t bother me because this was Star Wars. It really was.

The most disturbing scene was so hard to watch that Dan actually looked away (this was his second time, my first). It was seeing Anakin dismembered and burned. Extremely graphic and very disturbing, pretty far out there for a Star Wars movie. But again, it had to be. We all knew that there wasn’t much left that was human, after all. The parallel scenes of Padme’s death and Anakin’s rebirth as Darth Vader were exceptionally strong, too.

Anyway, I cried, and I really can’t get it out of my head. Those are the two major signs of an outstanding movie, as far as I’m concerned. I even want to go see it again in the theater, and I honestly don’t do that much any more. I can see the critics finding something wrong with it and they may even be right, but frankly, if people don’t find this movie totally engrossing, then they probably never really liked Star Wars in the first place.

Bits and pieces:

– How long was the break between Episodes 2 and 3? Anakin was clearly older; his face was scarred. Obi-Wan had grey at his temples.

– Chancellor Palpatine was such a minor player in the first two episodes. His seduction of Anakin and slow transformation into the Emperor was very effective. This was not an easy part to play. Samuel L. Jackson, who looked amazingly distinguished totally bald, did a fine job portraying the ambiguity that Anakin saw in the leader of the Jedi Council.

– They did some obvious echoes of Leia in Padme. The first time we see her, she’s wearing The Hair: the cinnamon buns over the ears Princess Leia do. Then she did Leia’s beige and brown look with the braid, too.

– Again, Lucas inserted bits that set up the earlier trilogy: Chewbacca, and the Wookiee army we should have gotten in Episode 6; a brief glance of the surface of Alderan; a quick glimpse of Grand Moff Tarkin.

– Perhaps George Lucas should have spread out some of the goodness in this film into the first two.

– The mass slaughter of the Jedis really got to me. Darth Vader slaughtering the younglings may have been the darkest moment in all six movies.

– Dismemberment again. Here, there were so many instances that I’m probably missing them: Count Dooku, Mace Windu, General Grevious, and of course, Darth Vader, who lost his remaining three limbs.

– There was a lot of stuff that could be interpreted as criticism of the Bush administration, and I never get tired of that. Palpatine literally tore up the Senate during that final duel with Yoda, symbolically tearing apart democracy.

– General Grievous was a reflection of the future Darth: gooey organics and mostly mechanical.

– I thought the PG-13 rating was appropriate. I wouldn’t take a small child to see this movie.

– Obi-Wan got to say it again. “Oh, I have a bad feeling about this.”

Four out of four stars,

Billie Doux loves good television and spends way too much time writing about it.

blog.name: masteraphra
blog.title: who wants to get rich?
blog.description:
prev. dagobah-luke

grace. disaster bi. aus.

summary:
initial thoughts after watching the original trilogy for the first time
the sets were SPICY
i absolutely fucking love luke...
body:
initial thoughts after watching the original trilogy for the first time

  • the sets were SPICY
  • i absolutely fucking love luke skywalker
  • his personality and goals and values are <3 he’s so interesting and changes from !!!! boi to understanding his feels and being a badass and most of all becoming jedi boi
  • leia is the woman i have needed my whole life
  • her attitude gives me LIFE
  • she’s not just a pretty face and i love that even though she’s kinda a forced damsel in distress at times but uhhh she’s just great
  • DON’T EVEN GET ME STARTED ON HAN SOLO
  • a thot
  • like. holy fuck. calm down.
  • he has an ego but its pretty clear that inside he just wants to do the right thing in the scheme of things but pff that won’t stop him from doing some petty morally questionable things
  • i <3 him so much shdhdb
  • i could say tons more but i wont
  • uhhh c-3po is a fucking MOOOOD
  • one of the most pessimistic characters i have ever seen from anything i fucking love him
  • him being treated as a god by the ewoks KILLED ME
  • jabba sure is one huge womaniser for some weird giant alien slug thing
  • the ships!!!!!!! nice!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
  • the costumes and sets are just so. star wars
  • luke’s inner turmoil when his whole life has been a lie bc his father didn’t die—he’s just darth vader. i got :(( because imagine how fucked he woulda felt
  • also ?? when he found out leia was his sister his 836353 emotions was :)
  • oh btw i think lukes my favourite but han makes me <3333333
  • not a huge fan of yoda but meh
  • obi wan made me :)
  • obi wan dying made me :(
  • every scene with vader and luke literally put knots in my stomach because they were just so TENSE
  • han solo’s protectiveness over the millenium falcon is like its some kind of child or pet lmaooo what a man <3
  • chewbacca jus wants to do good, especially by han
  • han’s protectiveness over luke is <3 we need more interactions between male characters like that

i could say a lot more but i’m sleepy so i won’t but mm from what i’ve seen i really like star wars

initial thoughts after watching the original trilogy for the first time

  • the sets were SPICY
  • i absolutely fucking love luke skywalker
  • his personality and goals and values are <3 he’s so interesting and changes from !!!! boi to understanding his feels and being a badass and most of all becoming jedi boi
  • leia is the woman i have needed my whole life
  • her attitude gives me LIFE
  • she’s not just a pretty face and i love that even though she’s kinda a forced damsel in distress at times but uhhh she’s just great
  • DON’T EVEN GET ME STARTED ON HAN SOLO
  • a thot
  • like. holy fuck. calm down.
  • he has an ego but its pretty clear that inside he just wants to do the right thing in the scheme of things but pff that won’t stop him from doing some petty morally questionable things
  • i <3 him so much shdhdb
  • i could say tons more but i wont
  • uhhh c-3po is a fucking MOOOOD
  • one of the most pessimistic characters i have ever seen from anything i fucking love him
  • him being treated as a god by the ewoks KILLED ME
  • jabba sure is one huge womaniser for some weird giant alien slug thing
  • the ships!!!!!!! nice!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
  • the costumes and sets are just so. star wars
  • luke’s inner turmoil when his whole life has been a lie bc his father didn’t die—he’s just darth vader. i got :(( because imagine how fucked he woulda felt
  • also ?? when he found out leia was his sister his 836353 emotions was :)
  • oh btw i think lukes my favourite but han makes me <3333333
  • not a huge fan of yoda but meh
  • obi wan made me :)
  • obi wan dying made me :(
  • every scene with vader and luke literally put knots in my stomach because they were just so TENSE
  • han solo’s protectiveness over the millenium falcon is like its some kind of child or pet lmaooo what a man <3
  • chewbacca jus wants to do good, especially by han
  • han’s protectiveness over luke is <3 we need more interactions between male characters like that

i could say a lot more but i’m sleepy so i won’t but mm from what i’ve seen i really like star wars

blog.name: mandowords
blog.title: Miit'alor
blog.description: I am a descriptivist linguist for the Mando'a language. I show what it can do, not what it MUST do. This is a place for discussion about Mando'a, and Mandalorian society and culture. Feel free to use the head cannons from this blog (or reblogged from others) in your RP or writing. All words and descriptions are taken from the mandoa.org Mandalorian Dictionary. Want to support this blog? Buy me a Kofi? OR buy some Mando'a themed items? Visit our Discord? Blog icon by Rina

summary: Look I'm not into the boycotting Star Wars thing but what are we going to do if JJ kills off Ben Solo? There won't be any more...
body:
Look I’m not into the boycotting Star Wars thing but what are we going to do if JJ kills off Ben Solo? There won’t be any more Star Wars, so he’ll never have a chance of coming back. Disney (Lucasfilms particularly) will definitely be under a lot of fire, but nothing will change. So are we just expected to let Ben be killed off? I guess that’s what they’re assuming. You know from a spoiler I heard both Rey and Ben are going to be killed off and if that happens a lot of people are going to be pissed. Exspecially since if you look at these two particular characters and how in a way they’ve impacted the world. Rey has been an inspiration to young girls and gave a glimpse of hope to some kid out there who never had a role model who was abandoned and told to fight for theirself like Rey had.

Ben has shown the world quite a lot. He’s a flaming ball of emo. I understand and I’ll flat out say it I am a flaming ball of emo too. Honestly Ben has been a role model for me. We know that it is canon that Han was gone for a lot of Ben’s childhood. That was also the time where he was abused by Snoke and started to turn dark. Then Luke tried to kill him. If you really think about it Ben probably felt unloved, like any child in that situation would. He ended up full of raw emotions and seems pretty lost in everything. He has issues with socializing, doesn’t know how to properly express his emotions, and wants to let go of the past so bad but it just doesn’t work like that. I see myself in that. My dad was gone a lot as a child, and when he was home he was a fiery ball of drunk exspecially after my uncle and grandma died. All of that led to a lot of unhappy memories. Now after all that has ended my family is happier, but things still get emotional sometimes. I have social anxiety (this makes school really hard because sometimes I just can’t handle a large class), I freak out over small things, I have broke a few things out of pure anger, I do cry (a lot), just because some days I really can’t handle the feeling of the past and I want it to go away. I never talk about my feelings about it because that doesn’t ever work in my favour. It’s left this emotional hole in my soul, and of course none other than Ben Solo aka Kylo Ren has been the character I’ve used to fill it.

If he were to die I’d never be able to cope because I’ve filled all my insecurities with my love for a fictional character named Ben Solo. If he died it would feel like a loved one dying.

I’m not the only one who feels that way, because I’ve talked to people in the same boat.

So I’d hope Disney would figure that out and not kill him off.

A lot of us would not be able to deal with Kylo and/or Rey dead. I get that it’s “just a movie” to most people, but to a lot of us in the fandom it’s more than that. It’s our childhood, it’s our reason to smile, it’s our emotional “security blanket”, it’s the reason we’ve made friends, it’s what we spend our time enjoying, it’s much more than just a movie and it’s characters are more than just characters, they’re who we see ourselves in and what let’s us know at night that it’s going to be okay no matter how big or small the struggle is.
